title: VIPs who passed on in 2024 - The Nation Newspaper
body_text:
Featured
December 28, 2024 by GBENGA ADERANTI
VIPs who passed on in 2024
Excluding the genocide in Gaza, the outgoing year had no significant disasters of mass fatalities in many parts of the world, including Nigeria. Of course, there would always be deaths, but the scale number appeared to be lower than occurred in previous years. This stands out the outgoing year as one of the least calamitous in terms of human deaths in Nigeria and the world at large. But as it is always the case, some very important persons (VIPs) bid the world goodbye in the outgoing year as hereunder highlighted by GBENGA ADERANTI
JANUARY
Mário Zagallo
The world lost one of the legends of the game of football, Mario Zagallo in January. The Brazillian died in the Brazillian capital, Rio de Janeiro, on January 5 at the age of 92.
Zagallo did not only play a prominent role in Brazilian and world football as a winger in the Brazilian team that won back-to-back World Cups in 1958 and 1962, starting in both finals.
He managed the side widely regarded as the greatest international team of all time, including Pele, Jairzinho and Carlos Alberto, to glory in 1970.
Zagallo’s final World Cup triumph came as Carlos Alberto Parreira’s assistant coach in 1994.
Franz Beckenbauer
A week after Zagallo’s death, Franz Beckenbauer, a German football legend, also passed on.
Born in Munich September 11 1945, Beckenbauer died in Salzburg, Austria on January 7, at the age of 78.
In his tribute to the former German football tactician, former England star, Gary Lineker, described him as “one of the absolute greats of our game”.
He had captained West Germany to World Cup victory in his home country in 1974 when the Netherlands were beaten in the final in Munich.
He replicated the feat as manager when Argentina were overcome in the 1990 final in Rome’s Stadio Olimpico, making up for the disappointment of losing to a Diego Maradona-inspired side in the final in Mexico four years earlier.
FEBRUARY
Bukar Abba Ibrahim
The death of former governor of Yobe State, Bukar Abba Ibrahim, on February 4, 2024 heralded the demise of some other prominent Nigerians.
The ebullient former governor died in the oil-rich country of Saudi Arabia at 75, after a protracted illness. He was a two-term governor, who also represented the people of Yobe East in the Senate.
Jimi Solanke
On February 5, while many were still mourning the passing of the ex-governor of Yobe State, Nigerian actor, dramatist, folk singer, poet and playwright, Jimi Solanke, also took many by surprise.
He died en route Olabisi Onabanjo University Teaching Hospital, Ago-Iwoye, Ogun State at the age of 81 after a brief illness.
Born in July 1942 in the Olowogbowo area of Lagos Island, Jimi’s journey from a curious child with a penchant for creation to a revered actor, folk singer, poet, and playwright is a tale of passion, perseverance and triumph.
Cairo Ojougboh
Prominent politician, Dr. Cairo Ojougboh, also succumbed to the cold hands of death in February. He was aged 64 when he passed on.
Ojougboh, a chieftain of the All Progressives Congress (APC) who represented Ika Federal Constituency in the House of Representatives, reportedly died in Abuja while watching the Nigeria versus South Africa semi-final AFCON match.
He also served as the Executive Director, Project, of the Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC).
He previously served the former President Ebele Jonathan administration as the former president’s adviser on National Assembly Matters.
Fatai Adams
Another politician and Chairman of the Ondo Chapter of the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), Mr Fatai Adams, died in the early hours of Wednesday, February 10.
Adams died in a private hospital in Akure, the Ondo state capital.
He was a member of the Ondo State House of Assembly between 2007 and 2011.
He also served as the deputy state chairman of the PDP in Ondo State.
Chike Edozien
Five months shy of 100 years, 99-year-old Asagba of Asaba, Obi (Prof) Chike Edozien also passed on in February.
Edozien’s academic career began with an appointment as a lecturer in Clinical Biochemistry in Middlesex Hospital Medical School, University of London in 1951.
In 1952 he was appointed a Senior Lecturer in Chemical Pathology at the University College, Ibadan, Oyo State.
He returned to Ibadan, Oyo State after further studies in Ireland.

Edozien is considered one of the most impactful figures in the history of medicine in Nigeria. Not only was he a pioneer in nutrition, laboratory science, pathology, research in the development of a malaria vaccine, the effects of vitamin C and protein intake on the body and in child development, he also pioneered the development of Physiotherapy as a degree course in Nigeria and educated the first cohort of laboratory scientists in Nigeria thereby establishing the pillars of both degree courses in Nigeria.
He was instrumental in the recognition of the School of Medicine at what is now University of Ibadan as a foremost institution on par with other international schools of medicine.
Fabian Osuji
Former Nigerian Minister of Education, Prof Fabian Osuji, also died in February at the age of 82.
According to a report, the former minister died barely four days after returning to the country from a foreign medical trip for an undisclosed ailment.
Born on 20 January, 1942, he attended Holy Ghost College, Owerri; Government College, Umuahia; the University of Nigeria, Nsukka in Enugu State and the University of Ibadan, Oyo State.
He performed his post-doctoral research at the Imperial College of Science and Technology, London and became a Lecturer, Senior Lecturer and Associate Professor in the Department of Zoology, University of Ibadan in 1973, a post he held till 1981.
Brian Mulroney
As the month of February was winding-up, the death occurred of the former Canadian Prime Minister, Brian Mulroney.
He was said to have died peacefully, surrounded by family, at the age of 84.
Announcing the late Canadian Prime Minister’s death, his daughter, Caroline, posted on X-handle: “On behalf of my mother and our family, it is with great sadness we announce the passing of my father, The Right Honourable Brian Mulroney, Canada’s 18th Prime Minister.”
He was the country’s 18th prime minister and was in office from 1984 to 1993.
Ali Hassan Mwinyi
Former Tanzanian President, Ali Hassan Mwinyi, a key figure in the nation’s transition to multi-party democracy, passed on at the age of 98.
He died on Thursday February 29.
His death was announced by the current President of Tanzania, Samia Suluhu Hassan, on a state television programme.
Mwinyi was said to have undergone treatment for lung cancer in a London hospital before returning to Tanzania for further medical care in Dar es Salaam.
He served as the second president of the United Republic of Tanzania from 1985 to 1995.
MARCH
Aluko-Olaseni
The death of a former Super Falcons goalkeeper Aluko-Olaseni came as a rude shock to many.
Only a few knew that the former Super Falcons goalkeeper was undergoing a challenge. Yet she was said to have battled cancer for eight years before she died March 2.
Mourning her death in a post on X, the Nigerian Football Federation (NFF) condoled with her family and prayed that she rests in peace.
Sometime in 2019, she had hinted about her cancer challenge to a news medium. She disclosed that the cancer developed in 2017 while she was playing for Rivers Angels in the Nigerian Women’s Premier League.
She explained that immediately after the cancer was detected, she was asked to undergo surgery, chemotherapy and radiation, which she did, and was forced to quit football because of the ailment.
Aluko-Olaseni was in goal for the Falcons between 2012 and 2013.
Paul Omotoso
Until his death in early March after a brief illness, Barr. Paul Omotoso was the chairman of the All Progressives Congress (APC) in Ekiti State.
The APC chairman, who was said to have actively attended political activities a Monday before his demise, complained of fever on Tuesday and was rushed to a hospital in Ado-Ekiti, the state capital, where he later died.
A party source said Omotoso had been experiencing failing health since his abduction by gunmen along the Imesi-Agbado Road in July, 2023.
He had served at different times as Commissioner for Housing and Environment; Commissioner for Special Duties and Commissioner for Local Government Affairs in the state.
Lekan Balogun
The 42nd Olubadan of Ibadanland, Oba Moshood Lekan Balogun, Alli Okunmade II, died on March 14, 2024 at the age of 81.
Confirming his passage, Oyo State governor ‘Seyi Makinde said the late Olubadan joined his ancestors at the University College Hospital (UCH), Ibadan.
He described Oba Balogun as a great Iroko tree, saying the late Olubadan was an epitome of royal excellence and a great achiever, who made great marks on Ibadanland in just a little over two years of his reign.
Balogun obtained Doctorate, Master’s and Bachelor’s degrees in Public Administration, Public and Social Administration, and Economics.
He attended Columbus International University and Manchester University in the United Kingdom.
He worked as a lecturer at the Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Kaduna State; as Editor of the monthly magazine, The Nigerian Pathfinder, and as a Director with Triumph Newspaper, Kano State.
He was a management consultant for multinational organisations such as Leyland, Exide Battery, and Nigerian Breweries.
Balogun worked with Shell British Petroleum Company where he rose to the position of Administrator/Head, Industrial Relations, Recruitment and Scholarships, Planning and Development units.
The late Alli Okunmade II represented the Oyo Central Senatorial District in the National Assembly between 1999 and 2003, where he served as the chairman of the Senate Committee on National Planning.
He was a governorship candidate of the defunct Nigeria People’s Party
Wole Oguntokun
A Nigerian playwright and theatre director, Wole Oguntokun, died in March at the age of 56.
Breaking the news on his Instagram page, his friend and film director, Kayode Peters, said: “I remember that year. I was just cutting my teeth as a professional theatre director. Your search for a director for your script brought you to the University of Lagos and I was your obvious choice
“I directed your first ever performance story ‘Who is Afriad of Wole Soyinka’ at various theatres including the prestigious Muson Centre, which was graced by the great @wolesoyinkaofficial himself
Some months later, we started DBN TV’s first comedy series, Crossworld Blues, which you produced and I directed.
“You moved to Canada and never stopped encouraging me to follow suit. I lost a friend, a thespian all through and through, a great mind, a writer so gifted, so loved. Nigeria just lost one of her brightest and bravest… Rest well my friend, my brother Wole Oguntokun @laspapi”
APRIL
Ali Chiroma
The death of ex-NLC president and former president of the Nigeria Labour Congress (NLC), Ali Chiroma, heralded the death of many prominent Nigerians who passed on in April.
The fiery labour leader died on April 2 at the University of Maiduguri Teaching Hospital.
He served as NLC president from 1984 to 1988.
Chiroma’s reign as NLC president came to an end in 1988 after the union was dissolved by Ibrahim Babangida, the former head of state.
In 1993, Sani Abacha, former military head of state, appointed Chiroma as head of the Nigeria Union of Petroleum and Natural Gas Workers (NUPENG).
Ahmad Belgore
The month of April must be special for former Justice of the Court of Appeal, Ahmad Belgore. He was born on April 18, 1953 and died a week before his 71st birthday.
He retired as a Justice of the appellate court on April 18, 2023, on attaining the retirement age of 70.
The NBA Ilorin Branch broke the news of the death of the retired Justice of the Court of Appeal.
He studied Law at the Ahmadu Bello University (ABU), Zaria, where he bagged a degree in Law with specialisation in Islamic Law.
Bright Esieme
The Nigerian football community was thrown into mourning with the death of a budding Nigerian footballer, Bright Esieme, on April 8. Esieme was a defender in the Super Eagles football team.
According to reports, Esieme, who was a member of the late Stephen Keshi’s home-based Super Eagles that featured at the African Nations Championship (CHAN) hosted by South Africa in 2014, died after a brief illness.
At the 2014 CHAN, he played as a left wingback, right wingback and holding midfielder as Nigeria ended the competition in the third position. He also played for Warri Wolves and Niger Tornadoes.
He hailed from Ukpakiri Kingdom in Abia State.
Ogbonnaya Onu
The political class and the people of Abia State on April 11 received the news of the death of the former governor of the State, Dr. Ogbonnaya Onu (CON) with shock.
Born on December 1, 1951, he died after a brief illness in an undisclosed hospital in Nigeria.
In 1991, he contested the position of Governor of Abia State on the platform of the National Republican Convention and won.
He was sworn in as the first executive governor of the state in January 1992.
He, however, had the shortest reign as a civilian governor in Abia State, having reigned for less than two years when the then military dictator, Gen. Sani Abacha overthrew the civilian administration.
Onu contested for the presidential ticket of the All Progressive Congress (APC) during the 2023 general election but lost it to President Bola Tinubu.
O. J. Simpson
Controversial American footballer, Orenthal James Simpson, popularly known as O. J. Simpson, who had a protracted battle with the United States government, died on April 11 of prostate cancer.
He was 76 at the time of his passing.

He was a celebrated Black American footballer, actor and broadcaster.
He played in the National Football League for 11 seasons, primarily with the Buffalo Bills, and is regarded as one of the greatest running backs of all time.
He rose to fame as a college athlete before playing for the NFL.
In 1994, his fame took a turn when he was arrested over the death of his former wife, Nicole Brown, and friend, Ron Goldman.
While the prosecution accused Simpson of being the murderer out of jealousy, his defence insisted he was a victim of conspiracy.
Simpson was said to be worth $38 million before he died.
MAY
Isa Dogonyaro
The lower Chamber of the National Assembly was thrown into mourning when the news of the death of 46-year-old lawmaker, Isa Dogonyaro, who represented Babura/Garki Federal Constituency, Jigawa State, broke.
Akin Rotimi, spokesperson of the House of Representatives, who announced Dogonyaro’s passing in a statement, said: “Hon. Isa Dogonyaro was a dedicated and passionate legislator who served his constituents and the nation with utmost commitment. the statement reads.
“He was a pillar in the House, contributing significantly to the development of legislation, particularly in the area of HIV/AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria Control, where he served as the Deputy Chairman of the House Committee.”
Rotimi said further that Dogonyaro was “known for his integrity, diligence, and unwavering dedication to the welfare of the Nigerian people.
“His presence will be sorely missed in the hallowed chambers of the House of Representatives.
“Hon. Isa Dogonyaro was a detribalised patriot who was very jovial as much as he was an intellectual.
Dogonyaro was a member of the All Progressives Congress (APC).
His passing came about six months after the death of Abdulkadir Danbuga.
Muhammadu Abubakar Ibn-Grema
The Emir of Tikau in Yobe, Alhaji Muhammadu Abubakar Ibn-Grema, died at the age of 70 years after a brief illness at a Specialists Hospital in the Potiskum area of Yobe State.
Ibn-Grema, whose palace is located in Nangere Local Government Area, was the paramount ruler of the Karekare people.
He was installed as Emir on July 25, 2001, and spent 23 years on the throne before his demise.
Joshua Obademi
Former Military Administrator of Benue State, Group Captain Joshua Obademi, died on Friday, May 10, 2024. He was 73.
Obademi was the Administrator of Benue State during the military regime of the late Gen. Sani Abacha, from December 1993 to August 1996.
Governor Hyacinth Alia of Benue State, in a statement, said the late administrator contributed greatly to the development of Benue, especially through the promotion of functional literacy for women in the state.
The governor noted that the functional literacy programme helped in the improvement of health and economic development of the state.
Alia said the history of Benue would be incomplete without the contributions of the late soldier.
Bola Afonja
Described as the golden boy of Oyo, Minister of Labour under Ernest Shonekan, Prince Ajibola Afonja, died on May 19.
Born on February 21, 1943, he was said to have sustained injuries from an accident in his ancestral town Oyo, but was later taken to University College Hospital in Ibadan, Oyo State where he eventually passed on at the age of 81.
He was a politician and philanthropist.
He was once a member of the board of trustees of the All Nigeria Peoples Party (ANPP).
Afonja was also the Chairman of the Board of Directors of First Bank plc.
He retired from the board following his 70th birthday on 21 February 2013.
Ibrahim Lamorde
Former Chairman of the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC), Ibrahim Lamorde, died at the age of 61.
The report said Lamorde died around 3am local time in Cairo, Egypt, three days after undergoing surgery.
Report said although the surgery was deemed successful, he reportedly developed complications three days later, May 25.
Born on 20 December 1962, Lamorde joined the Nigerian Police in 1986 and retired as a Deputy Inspector General of Police in 2021.
He served as EFCC chairman between 2011 and 2015.
He was the third Executive Chairman of the Commission.
He was appointed in an acting capacity as Chairman of the Commission on 3 November 2011 following the removal of Farida Waziri by former President Goodluck Jonathan.
He was confirmed as the third substantive Chairman of the Commission by the Senate on February 15, 2012.
Ebrahim Raisi
It is more than six months since the former Iranian President, Sayyid Ebrahim Raisolsadati, better known as Ebrahim Raisi, died in a helicopter crash at the age of 64, but many still believe that the accident was contrived.
His helicopter crashed on May 19 in Iran’s East Azerbaijan province .
He was the eighth president of Iran from 2021 until his death.
He was loved by hardliners of the Islamic Republic of Iran for his loyalty and obedience to Iran’s supreme leader.
JUNE
Gilbert Ajulu Uzodike
It was a tragedy for the family members of the Founder of Cutix Cables and Wire, Engr. Gilbert Ajulu Uzodike (OON), who died a few months after his birthday.
The Nnewi-born business mogul and philanthropist passed away in the early hours of June 7, a few months after marking his 79th birthday on March 25.
The industrialist, who hailed from Ndi-Ogbe Otolo, Nnewi, was also the founder of the defunct Adtec Limited and Adswitch Plc.
His brand, the Cutix Cables, founded in 1981, is known for manufacturing and marketing electrical, automobile and telecommunication wires, cables and related products.
He ws also into production of aluminum twist cables, armoured cables, bare aluminum conductor, flexible or auto cables, and regular cables.
Until his death, Chief Uzodike was reputed as one of the most successful or the richest Igbo businessmen who distinguished themselves in the manufacturing sector.
Femi Esho
As the manufacturing sector was smarting from the death of Gilbert Uzodike, the entertainment industry also had a dose of death’s sting as the Chairman Evergreen Musical Company and founder Evergreen Music Heritage Foundation, Mr. Babafemi Esho, passed on at the age of 77.
He died on Monday, June 17 after a brief illness, barely one month after partnering Dr. DK Odukoya to launch the biggest music empire in Africa, the Evergreen Music Heritage Foundation.
A statement by his son, Bunmi Esho, said: “We announce the passing unto glory of our Patriarch, Mr Samuel Babafemi Esho popularly known and referred to as ‘Baba Esho’, Baba Musician, etc.
“Baba Esho departed to greater glory on Monday 17th June 2024 after a brief illness at the age of 77 years.
Baba Esho until his demise was the Chairman of the Evergreen Musical Company as well as the Founder of the Evergreen Music Heritage Foundation.
“Baba Esho was a mentor and “encyclopedia” to many ‘Highlife music aficionados.
Ibrahim Ogohi
As the month was about to come to a close, the news of the death of former Chief of Defence Staff, Ibrahim Ogohi, filtered in.
According to family sources, Ogohi died on a Sunday morning in Abuja.
Ogohi was the Chief of Defence Staff between 1999 and 2003.
He was the first naval officer to reach a four-star rank in the Nigerian military and the first Chief of Defence Staff from the navy.
He joined the Nigeria Defence Academy (NDA) in 1968 and received training in India, the UK, France, and the US.
JULY
Funso Aiyejina
Relatively known in Nigerian, Funso Aiyejina was very impactful in Trinidad and Tobago where he was a university teacher until he died on July 1.
A source said he died in his sleep. He was 75 years old.
Aiyejina was the Dean of Humanities and Education and Professor Emeritus at the University of the West Indies’ (UWI) St. Augustine campus, and was well loved by students and colleagues alike, hence his sudden passing was a shock to both the academics and the regional literary community of which he was an integral part.
He was born in 1949 in Ososo, a town in Nigeria’s Edo State.
Musiliudeen Olaide Akinremi
A member of the House of Representatives representing Ibadan North Federal Constituency, Hon. Musiliudeen Olaide Akinremi, was the first politician to die in July.
He died at the age of 51.
The federal lawmaker popularly popularly called Jagaban was a two-term member of the Federal House of Representatives.
He was a member of the All Progressives Congress (APC) .
AUGUST
Issa Hayatou
Issa Hayatou, the longest serving President of the Confederation of African Football, died on August 8, 2024, a day before his 78th birthday.
He was born on August 9, 1946 in Garoua, Cameroon.
Hayatou’s death was made known by FIFA President, Gianni Infantino, in a post on his Instagram stories.
Infantino wrote: “Saddened to hear of the passing of former CAF President, former FIFA President and interim, FIFA Vice President and FIFA Council member, Issa Hayatou.
“As a passionate sports fan and IOC member, he dedicated his life to sports administration and on behalf of FIFA, and condolences go to his family, friends, former colleagues and all who knew him. Rest in peace.”
He served as the president of CAF for 29 years, leading the organisation from 1988 until his unexpected ouster in 2017.
Wole Diya
A day after the death of former CAF president, death came knocking on the door of a Nigerian politician, Wole Diya.
Diya, a former member of the House of Representatives, Somolu Federal Constituency 1, died at 63.
The two-term representative of Somolu Federal Constituency in the Green Chamber died early Friday, August 9, 2024. He died a few days before his 64th birthday which was expected to come up on Tuesday, August 20.
Diya was a younger brother to former Chief of Defence Staff, the late General Oladipo Diya.
John Amos
‘Coming to America’ Actor John Amos passed away at 84 on August 21.
The Afro-American actor was born 27 December ,1939 in the United States.
Amos reportedly died of congestive heart failure at Centinela Hospital Medical Center in Inglewood, California
An Emmy nominee,
Amos, an actor best known for his roles in ‘Good Times,’ ‘where he played the role of James Evans Sr, ‘The Roots,’ as adult Junta Kinte and ‘Coming to America’ where he played the role of an African King and the father of Prince Akeem (Eddy Murphy).
Christian Obi
It was a trying time for the management and supporters of Heartland FC, Owerri, Imo State when the Head Coach of the club, Christian Power Obi, died in a car accident.
In a statement shared by the club, Obi died of injuries he sustained after the team bus was involved in a crash in Okigwe, Imo State.
The statement revealed that players and staff of the Nigerian Professional Football League (NPFL) club were on their way to participate in the TICO/SELECT Ifeanyi Ekwueme pre-season tournament in Ebonyi when the accident occurred.
The accident involved one of the team’s three vehicles “which rammed into a carelessly parked truck while attempting to avoid an oncoming vehicle”.
Sven-Gora Eriksson
As the month of August was about to come to a close, the news came of the death of former England manager, Sven-Goran Eriksson.
Eriksson died on August 26 at the age of 76.
He was the first non-British manager of the England team, led the Three Lions to the quarter-finals at three major tournaments during his five-year spell in charge between 2001 and 2006.
Early in the year, Eriksson said he had “at best” a year to live after being diagnosed with cancer.
His children, Lina and Johan, said: “Our father Sven-Goran Eriksson fell asleep peacefully in his home at Bjorkefors outside Sunne this morning. He has for a long time fought bravely with his illness, but now it came to an end.
“Dad told us at the beginning of this year about his serious illness and received an amazing response from friends and football fans around Europe.
“He was invited to several football teams in England, Italy, Portugal and Sweden. They shared their love for football and for dad.”
Nojim Maiyegun
As if the sports legends planned to die the same day, while the English and the Swedes were mourning the death of Eriksson, Nigerians also were thrown into dejection over the news of the demise of legend boxer and first Nigerian Olympic medalist, Nojim Maiyegun.
He died at 83.
The death of the legendary boxer was confirmed in a Facebook post by Rudolfine F Soultan, a confidante, on Monday.
“My Jimmy died. I can’t say more about this right now because it’s just horrible. The day after tomorrow, we would have been together for 17 years,” the post reads.
Maiyegun, who became visually impaired a few years ago, was reportedly battling an unnamed illness for a couple of months.
He was the first Nigerian to win an Olympic medal.
Maiyegun was 23 when he won a bronze medal in the light-heavyweight boxing category at Tokyo 1964.
Sifiso Dabengwa
A former CEO of MTN Group, Sifiso Dabengwa, passed away in late August.
He was reported to have battled with cancer.
Dabengwa was the CEO at MTN from March 2011 until 2015, when he resigned amid the company’s efforts to address a substantial fine of ₦1.04 trillion imposed by Nigeria for failing to disconnect over five million customers with unregistered SIM cards.
Originally from Zimbabwe, Dabengwa also had a brief tenure as the CEO of MTN Nigeria until 2006.
SEPTEMBER
Hajia Dada Yar’Adua
Hajia Dada was the mother of the former Nigerian president, Umaru Yar’Adua.
Dada Yar’Adua died in Katsina on September 2 at the age of 102 after a protracted illness.
Her death was announced in a statement by one of her sons and the Chairman of the Senate Committee on Army, Abdulaziz Yar’Adua, through his media aide, Abdul Hassan.
Her death came 14 years after the passing of one of her sons and former Nigeria President, Umaru Yar’Adua, and 27 years after her eldest son, Shehu Yar’Adua, a military general, died.
Dele Agbeyo
Nigerian Gospel artiste, Dele Agbeyo a.k.a. Dele Gold, died a month after the death of Aduke Ajayi a.k.a. Aduke Gold.
The self-proclaimed Miliki Gospel King hailed from Usi, Ekiti State, but grew up in Faforiji, Osun State. He reportedly died after a brief illness.
Tito Jackson
Tito Jackson, a member of the renowned music group, Jackson 5, and brother to the late pop star Michael Jackson, died at 70 “after suffering heart attack”.
Tito, a founding member of the legendary family band, the Jacksons 5, comprising of Michael, Jemaine, Jackie and Marlon, died in September.
“It’s with heavy hearts that we announce that our beloved father, Rock & Roll Hall of Famer Tito Jackson is no longer with us. We are shocked, saddened and heartbroken.
“Our father was an incredible man who cared about everyone and their well-being,” a statement shared by his children TJ, Taj and Taryll on Instagram reads.
Tito, the third of nine Jackson children, died after suffering an apparent heart attack.
Born Toriano Adaryll Jackson on October 15, 1953, in Gary, Indiana, Tito was a key part of the Jackson family’s musical dynasty, formed in the 1960s.
The pop group released hit songs like ‘I Want You Back,’ ‘ABC’ and ‘I’ll Be There’ in the ’70s. The band was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1997 and was also honored with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.
Beyond his work with The Jackson 5, Tito pursued a solo career. He delivered his debut album ‘Tito Time’ in 2016.
Gabriel Aromolaran
Also in September, the Owa Obokun of Ijesha, Oyo State, Oba Gabriel Aromolaran, joined his ancestors at 87.
He was a first class Osun monarch who reigned for 42 years.
He was the Chairman of Osun State Council of Traditional Rulers.
According to a report, he was admitted at the Obafemi Awolowo University Teaching Hospital, Ile-Ife, Osun State, before he passed on.
OCTOBER
Peter Fregene
Football fraternity early in October lost one of their own, former Nigeria International goalkeeper Peter Fregene, at 77.
He died on Sunday, October 13.
Fregene died in the presence of Tina, his wife, and two of his children after a protracted illness at a hospital in Oghara, Delta State.
NOVEMBER
Quincy Jones
One of the most successful Afro-American record producers, composer, arranger, conductor, trumpeter, and bandleader, Quincy Jones, died November 3 at the age of 91.
Unconfirmed reports said Jones died from pancreatic cancer, which he had been battling for years.
Jones won 28 Grammy Awards out of 80 nominations, including a Grammy Legend Award in 1992.
He also received the Kennedy Center Honors in 2001 and the National Medal of the Arts from President Obama in 2011.
He produced Michael Jackson with other successful American musicians.
Taoreed Lagbaja
It was a great tragedy for the country when the Chief of Army Staff, Lt Gen Taoreed Lagbaja, died in November.
Lagabja was said to have died after a “period of illness” aged 56.
For some weeks, there were speculations about the health condition of the late army chief.
Confirming the demise of the late army chief in a statement shared on X by presidential spokesperson Bayo Onanuga, President Tinubu expressed his “heartfelt condolences” to Gen Lagbaja’s family.
“President Tinubu wishes Lt General Lagbaja eternal peace and honors his significant contributions to the nation,” the statement read.
His passing marked a significant loss for the Nigerian Armed Forces, where he “played pivotal roles in numerous internal security operations”, it said.
Chief of army staff is the highest-ranking military officer in the Nigerian army.
Lagbaja was appointed to the position in June 2023, not long after President Tinubu took office.
Before joining the army, Gen Lagbaja attended St Charles Grammar School, Osogbo, Osun State. He went on to join the Nigerian Defence Academy in 1987, starting his military career.
He later obtained an Msc in Strategic Studies from the US Army War College in Pennsylvania.
DECEMBER
Godwin Abe
A former Nigerian Army Major General, Godwin Abe, died on December 21 at the age of 75.
He served variously as Minister of Defence from 2009 to 2010, Minister of Interior from 2007 to 2009 and Military Administrator of Akwa Ibom and Rivers states.
He died in Abuja after a protracted illness.
